text: butchering or taking apart a whole
chicken has incredible advantages and
many people never bother to learn how to
do it but it's really easy I'm going to
show you how address the chicken chicken
you're going to notice that very often
there will be some excess fat in here
and you can just pull that out there may
be extra fat in other places now you've
got the breasts the legs the wings and
the backbone first thing you want to do
is take out the backbone there's a seam
along either side of the backbone and
you just start right here at the tail
bone and cut right down and right
through this is actually the most
difficult part same thing on the other
side
and you can see if for example right
here you've got a sticking point you
just look at it you can see there's a
bone right there you're going to have to
cut around having taken out the backbone
we've got a chicken that's pretty much
falling apart
I mean imagine it's got its backbone
missing so one at a time you take off
the appendages with the wings there's a
joint right here but I like to go on the
carcass or the breast side of the joint
take a little bit of white meat with it
because it makes the wing a better piece
to eat the legs are practically falling
off at this point there's nothing
holding them to the breasts except skin
once you remove the backbone so here you
just cut right down through that skin
and you can do this from the other side
also
there's nothing but skin right here and
right here
with the breast you want to cut right
through the breastbone so here you want
your chef's knife couple taps with the
knife right through just a big piece of
meat so I like to cut each of these in
half and just a final refinement with
the wings you have three sections of
what sometimes it's called the drumette
have this which is really great eating
two bones part and you have this wing
tip which is really not worth much so
just to have a little more for the
stockpot the wing tips go over here if
you want to separate the leg from the
thigh often done I like to do it there's
a joint right here you might not be able
to see in there but once your knife is
in there it's going to naturally find
the place where the joint is right where
those two bones meet if you don't find
it right away so you're going a little
too far to this side and you hit bone
just move the knife till you find that
joint you're going to find it it's right
in there so you're not really hacking
through bone there you're really finding
the space where the two bones meet and
you're cutting through cartilage so what
are the benefits of all this you get to
buy the chicken you want because the
best chicken is usually not sold in
parts you get some stuff for stock
you're closer to your food you've worked
on your knife skills and I don't see
that there could be anything wrong with
that all at all this is a no-brainer
